com.datamelt.rules.core

Class RuleGroup

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.datamelt.rules.core.RuleGroup
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class RuleGroup
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    Rules are organized in groups and subgroups. Subgroups can contain multiple rules and groups can contain multiple subgroups. Subgroups and rules can be connected using [and] or [or] conditions. rule groups are defined in xml files. one xml file can only contain one group. one can also say, that one rulegroup (and therefore one file) defines a rule scenario of a number of rules (one to many rules).
    Author:
    uwe geercken
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • getFailed

        public int getFailed()
              throws java.lang.Exception
        the subgroups can be combined using either a logical 'and' or a logical 'or'. the logical operator is stored with the subgroup and expresses how to logically combine the subgroup to the PREVIOUS subgroup. the first subgroup will be combined with the second subgroup. the result is a '0' or '1' (passed or failed). then the result will be compared to the next/third subgroup using the logical operator of the third subgroup. here is the logic in a diagram form: 0--- |---result--- 1--- |---result--- 2--- |---result--- 3--- in total one can say that the subgroups are chained together using the logical operators. the result is an indicator, if the complete group failed (0) or not (1).
        Returns:
        indicator if the rulegroup failed
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception if the result could not be determined

      • getFailedAsString

        public java.lang.String getFailedAsString()
                                   throws java.lang.Exception
        returns a string expression meaning [true] or [false] depending if the group passed or failed.
        Returns:
        indicator if the rulegroup failed
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception if the reult could not be determined

      • getFailed

        private int getFailed(int group1Failed,
                      int group2Failed,
                      int operator)
        returns (0 or 1) if two subgroups fail when you connect them using the defined condition [and] or [or] used to evaluate the result when chaining groups together
        Parameters:
        group1Failed - indicator if the first subgroup failed
        group2Failed - indicator if the second subgroup failed
        operator - the operator how the subgroups are connected to each other
        Returns:
        indicator if the chained subgroups failed

        Returns:
        the logic of a rulegroup in a textual representation

        public int getOutputType()
        specifies if all rule results should be output (2), only for failed rules (0), only for passed rules (1). default is 0.

        the output type
